verses.verse: ((2 Eliphaz affirmeth that Job is punished for his sins.6 He accuseth him of unmercifulness.13 And that he denied God’s providence.21 He exhorteth to repentance.) ) Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered, and said,

May a man be (Though man were just, yet God could have no profit of this his justice: and therefore when he punished him, he hath no regard to his justice, but to his sin.) profitable unto God, as he that is wise may be profitable to himself?
(Cross references: : Job 35:7) Is it anything unto the Almighty, that thou art righteous? or is it profitable to him, that thou makest thy ways upright?
Is it for fear (Lest thou shouldest reprove or hurt him?) of thee that he will accuse thee? or go with thee into judgment?
Is not thy wickedness great, and thine iniquities innumerable?

For thou hast taken the (Thou hast been cruel and without charity, and wouldest do nothing for the poor, but for thine own advantage.) pledge from thy brother for nought, and spoiled the clothes of the naked.
To such as were weary, thou hast not given water to drink, and hast withdrawn bread from the hungry.
But the mighty man (When thou wast in power and authority, thou didst not justice but wrong.) had the earth, and he that was in authority, dwelt in it.
Thou hast cast out widows empty, and the arms of the (Thou hast not only not showed pity, but oppressed them.) fatherless were broken.
Therefore snares are round about thee, and fear shall suddenly trouble thee.
Or darkness that thou shouldest not see, and (That is, manifold afflictions.) abundance of waters shall cover thee.

Is not God on (He accuseth Job of impiety and contempt of God, as though he would say, If thou pass not for men, yet consider the height of God’s majesty.) high in the heaven? and behold the height of the (That so much the more by that excellent work thou mayest fear God, and reverence him.) stars how high they are.
But thou sayest, How should God (He reproveth Job, as though he denied God’s providence and that he could not see the things that were done in this world.) know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
The clouds hide him that he cannot see, and he walketh in the circle of heaven.
Hast thou marked the way of the world, (How God hath punished them from the beginning?) wherein wicked men have walked?

Which were (He proveth God’s providence by the punishment of the wicked, whom he taketh away before they can bring their wicked purposes to pass.) cut down before the time, whose foundation was as a river that overflowed:
Which said unto God, Depart from us, and asked what the Almighty could do for them.

Yet he (He answereth to that which Job had said, Job 21:7, that the wicked have prosperity in this world: desiring that he might not be partaker of the like.) filled their houses with good things: but let the counsel of the wicked be far from me.

The righteous shall see them, and shall rejoice, (The just rejoice at the destruction of the wicked for two causes: first, because God showeth himself judge of the world and by this means continueth his honor and glory: secondly, because God showeth that he hath care over his in that he punished their enemies.) and the innocent shall laugh them to scorn.
Surely (That is, the state and preservation of the godly, is hid under God’s wings.) our substance is hid: but the fire hath devoured the remnant of (Meaning, of the wicked.) them.
Therefore acquaint thyself, I pray thee, (He exhorteth Job to repentance, and to return to God.) with him, and make peace: thereby thou shalt have prosperity.
Receive, I pray thee, the law of his mouth, and lay up his words in thine heart.
If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt (God will restore unto thee all thy substance.) be built up, and thou shalt put iniquity far from thy tabernacle.
Thou shalt lay up gold for (Which shall be in abundance like dust.) dust, and the gold of Ophir, as the flints of the rivers.
Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defense, and thou shalt have plenty of silver.
And thou shalt then delight in the Almighty, and lift up thy face unto God.
Thou shalt make thy prayer unto him, and he shall hear thee, and thou shalt render thy vows.
Thou shalt also decree a thing, and he shall establish it unto thee, and the (That is, the favor of God.) light shall shine upon thy ways.

(God will deliver his when the wicked are destroyed round about them, as in the flood and in Sodom.) When others are cast down, then shalt thou say, I am lifted up: and God shall save the humble person.
The innocent shall deliver the (God will deliver a whole country from peril, even for the just man’s sake.) island, and it shall be preserved by the pureness of thine hands.
